#Text=2. Indoor Localization Framework and Strategies
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=System Architecture and Path-Loss Propagation Model
#Text=Zigbee is a low-cost wireless communication technology based on the IEEE 802.15.4 standard , which is often used to create personal area networks .
#Text=Due to its low power consumption and secure networking capabilities , it is often preferable for wireless control and monitoring in smart-building technologies .

#Text=In this study , we use XBee embedded modules with the Zigbee protocol to create four transmitters that are placed at preassigned positions , and one receiver which is the target node to be localized .

#Text=In order to introduce mobility to the target node and to verify the proposed indoor localization strategies , NSBot2 , which is a nonholonomic wheeled mobile robot was built with ATMega microcontrollers connected to the target node as shown in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=With regard to control mechanism , NSbot2 was preprogrammed with closed-loop cascade control where its motion was constrained to constant translational and rotational velocities .
#Text=This technique does not just allow the robot to travel along various types of planned path , but it also enables each experiment with a specific path to be repeated with minimal variations .

#Text=The basic idea for indoor localization with RSSI is that the target node to be localized stays at a fixed coordinate , and the RSSI from different anchor nodes with known positions are measured .

#Text=RSSI values can be converted into distances using a path-loss model , which are then used with the triangulation , multilateration , or trilateration method to estimate the position of the target node .
#Text=One of the most commonly used path-loss propagation models in a WSN is the log-distance function .

#Text=Via this model , the value of RSSI , ( in dBm ) can be theoretically expressed as follows : ( 1 ) where d ( in m ) is the distance between transmitter ( anchor node ) and receiver ( target node ) , is the free space reference distance , typically 1 m , is the path-loss exponent coefficient , and is the RSSI value when the transmitter and the receiver are 1 m apart , which in this case is found to be dBm .
#Text=The theoretical value for with some calibrations is 1.8 .
#Text=From Equation ( 1 ) , the distance d can be simply retrieved with : ( 2 )
#Text=In real situations , when the target node is continuously moving , the effects of noise from multipath propagation , signal occlusions , and diffractions can be undesirably amplified .
#Text=Hence , the theoretical RSSI-distance relation in Equation ( 1 ) may no longer be sufficient to predict the actual path-loss model .

#Text=In order to estimate the real distance for a continuously moving node more accurately , sampled data for are collected when the transmitter is placed at a fixed coordinate , and the receiver , named Node M , is moved at a speed of approximately 20 cm/s from cm until cm .
#Text=This is illustrated in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=.
#Text=A curve-fitting method is then utilized to generate an improved path-loss propagation model , , as follows : ( 3 ) where ; and n is the number of sampled data .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=RSSI-Based Localization

#Text=In this work , four transmitters were configured as anchor nodes ( Anchors A , B , C , and D ) ; hence , four distance values can be obtained at each time instance from the path-loss propagation model .
#Text=They are also placed at points where any three of them are always noncollinear , which ensures the feasibility of the trilateration method at each time instance .
#Text=Consider as the unknown coordinate of the mobile node , and with be the first three coordinates from three different anchor nodes received by the mobile node .
#Text=Let be the estimated distance from Node M to , and ( 4 ) where ( 5 )
#Text=The coordinate of the mobile node can then be retrieved via Cramer ’s rule as follows : ( 6 )
#Text=2.3 .
#Text=Odometry
#Text=Odometry is a process of estimating the position change of a mobile robot on the basis of data from motion sensors .
#Text=For this research , the encoders on both wheels of the mobile robot were used to estimate the path taken as well as the heading direction .
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=illustrates the robot ’s position with respect to two different frames , namely and . denotes the world coordinate system , whereas represents the robot-attached frame .
